description: From Latin fābulātus, perfect passive participle of fābulor (“tell stories, chat”), from fābula (“fable”).

verbs.description: fabulate (third-person singular simple present fabulates, present participle fabulating, simple past and past participle fabulated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To tell invented stories, often those that involve fantasy, such as fables.
examples: Human fears, needs, dreams release the latent propensities of the subliminal soul, and to respond to them the fabulating imagination sets to work.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To relate as or in the manner of a fable.
(intransitive, obsolete) To tell fables, to narrate with fables.

description: Coined around 1934 by folklorist Carl von Sydow to contrast with memorate.

entries.meaning: A folk story that is not entirely believable.
(specifically) A folk story that is told for entertainment, and not intended to be taken as true.
